projects-description: CS graduate • studying AI • learning how to better shoot on film format • capturing portraits and concerts • taking pictures just for fun • figuring out this blog

content.header: One recurrent theme I encountered when talking to people is that they are searching for great spots, or abandaned places, where to go take pictures. Nobody cares about the place, but the story you are telling.

paragraphs: The second month of this peculiar summer found me alone in a near abandoned South Texas senior citizen RV resort. The air was as ominous as it was humid, a premonition of Hurricane Hanna ravaging Hidalgo County, filling up the empty lake, and knocking out my power for two days. I took a walk through a gloom dominated by palm trees and a pre-storm sky with my headphones on. This is where Lucrecia Dalt’s No era sólida (Spanish for ‘I Was Not Solid’) unravelled itself.

The Colombian avant-garde sound artist, based in Berlin by way of Pereira, has crafted a work that conjures a macabre suspense through the morphology of the voice. Dalt’s multi-disciplinary and disjointed musicianship can be traced to her background as a geotechnical engineer, a professional grounding in the physical world that lies in stark opposition with her musical approach.

content.header: At the same time this festival was expanding, I was learning how to become a concert photographer. If I were to define a function to depict my evolution with respect to time, it would be a funny-shaped 2D line, mostly influenced by people I met over the years.
paragraphs: Last year I met a couple, husband and wife, at a festival where I find it hard to imagine foreigners. While shooting a band I saw a tall guy approaching the pit, with a tone of gear hanging his waist. Not far behind was a lady, with quite the same equipment. I was blown away. I knew they weren't there to cover the festival, but what were they there for?

Naturally, I asked them what were they doing, and the lady was more inclined to tell me their story. After a couple of minutes, she told me she grew up in Romania. She came to Romanian to show her husband where she was born. We kept talking about their journey when out of a sudden, her husband handed me 'hand sanitizer'.

It wasn't originally intended to be used that way, but it could be very well. The bottle was containing a very strong alcohol-based drink, called 'tuica' - a traditional drink from Romania. This simple act of sharing touched me like nothing has touched me before when meeting some people. We are offering 'tuica' at feasts, or to welcome someone at our table. He was not speaking my language, yet he found a way to communicate with me in a manner he saw here, on these lands.
I don't usually drink this sort of beverage, so I took a sip and told them that it is not 'hand sanitizer', it is more like 'rocket fuel'. They nodded with a similar grimace I had.

After bumpy trip to Bontida, the festival site, I started following the signs towards the organizer's tent. As I was waiting in line to get my badge, I started chatting with some friends, and the conversation went long after a young lady started to ask my credentials. When she asked me what type of badge I need, I replied simply that I wanted a photo badge, and went on. It took me 30 seconds to realize I've got a kick-ass badge, a stunning piece of plastic.

The badges I got until then were arguably ugly. As they were designing them to indirectly tell you how much access you got. I bet there was a jinn whispering 'hehe, wait to see what's coming for you'. The first day went pretty fast and I never got the chance to access the main stage. All the bands I was interested in photographing were on the second stage, the air-shed. That's the great thing about planning what you want to cover.

On the second day I wanted to cover the band I stared photography, Alternosfera. I went to the main stage access area, waiting for the band to begin. The security searched me for a rough edge, but I was sure I had the right type of access, so I insisted. I felt relief when I stepped foot on the channel connecting the sound tent with the pit area.

Remember when I was telling you that a badge tells you how much access you get?

Yeah, right..

After a while, all those who were the lucky owners of a black & yellow badge got an upgrade to a black & yellow (+) magenta sticker. Life was telling me that my access just got restricted.

Even so, I was determined to figure it out. I went to the main stage, got rejected by the security as I wasn't upgraded to the new color scheme and I started to ask questions. The type of answer I got was 'Find R, she'll tell you what to do'. So I went searching for someone named R. You won't believe it when I tell you I found them, but they told me to 'find A'.

So I did.

Let's wrap it up. I found T, and he asked me what was going on with my badge. He told me that I got the wrong one. It was meant for the photo crew, not for photo press.

Oh, snap!

So that's why I missed the upgrade. To be honest, I got it when I started to run around after the alphabet, but you cannot judge me for my curiosity. I told T that the young lady from the first tent gave it to me. T corrected the mistake in less than 10 seconds. You give me that one, I give you this one - non-negotiable.

You might think that it was restricting me even more, but the badge only had the third color scheme. I asked for it and I knew I'll learn something, retrospectively, but it wasn't refreshing.

This story is not about breaking the rules. I am an obedient person, but a curious one. I followed the rules, and even pointed to a flow in their organization. I wanted to see how this situation is evolving. Throughout this journey, I learned how to communicate with those organizing the festival, met the artists and improved my skills.

The first picture you see in this post was shot from the crowd, a few moments after I got pulled out from the mosh pit. Would it be better framed if I were in the pit?

Yes, most probably.

But let me ask you something. How often have you been pulled out from the mosh pit by two guys yelling 'This one is a photographer', squeezed against the baricades yelling at the security agent to let you, somehow, leave that spot as you were carying expensive gear, and yet tell the world to go to hell and continue taking pictures? Not often I guess.

Use your time wisely, don't waste it for someone's approval.

First time I ever attended Summer Well was back in 2016. The process of getting a badge had a learning curve, yet I got one of these in 2018 and become a crew member in 2019. None of these things would not have happened if not for the people with whom I met. They are a group of photographers from Cluj-Napoca, Komiti, and an amazing manager, Valentin.

I met Valentin in the press area, which was a cozy little building somewhere in the middle of the park, really close to the main stage. I never hoped for free water, food, coffee.. yet Valentin was extremely kind. As kind as I imagine british to be.

While talking I said that it would be nice to be able to cover the bands from the photo pit, but I wasn't allowed at that moment, based on some meritocracy related reasons. He immediately said that he's deciding how is going into the pit, and that we leave in 5 minutes.

Wohou!

Hold my cup. Do we?

He never knew that he allowed me to shoot for the first time from the pit, at a medium size festival, the very band I met one year later at EC, where I hugged them and got their autographs. Wasn't that nice?

On the same note, reaching out to a colleague of mine, Alex Balas, which on his turn connected me to Marius Maris, gave me the chance of meeting Komiti. They asked me if I would like to come with them to an event, near Cluj-Napoca, at Bontida, where EC takes places every year.

Yes! At Banffy Castle? Hah, of course!

Before that I tought I met frendly people. Oh, dear! I still remember that Vlad said at one point that he lives for 'piscotareala'. In other words, we photographed, took a bite and enjoyed the party.

After that I kept hanging aroung, asking questions, listening to their advice, and applying it. In the end, the most important aspect of this story is that you should ask, tell and listen. I call it building a social network.

content.header: Hi there! Alex here. One of my all time passions is learning, both from people and making computers learn.
paragraphs: The idea of making a blog got into my head while and it never left. The thinking process was quick simple. I know things that some people might find useful and learn from my experience. I started coding this website, but it went on the pile of paused projects once I had to finish my bachelor thesis. Since I was little, having a personal website was a dream of mine.

I graduated the class of 2020 from the Babes-Bolyai University, Computer Science department, then got enrolled into the next adventure. Currently I am studying Applied Computational Intelligence, or AI. I kept capturing people because that is what fascinated me in the begging. This thing is keeping me busy, I got the chance to meet new people, and from time to time build a relationship.

The second main thing I find fascinating about photography is that pictures don't have a preorganized manner in which they land on the storage. There is so much to learn from a photography. What does it take to have a special picture? Maybe some of the question I have in my head can be, one day, solved using a computer. Maybe they can't.

These are the main facts you should know about me. I simply enjoy taking pictures and looking at them over time. Digital age made it simple and very accessible, yet it's been a while since I got a camera and I never felt more joyful than when I was sweatty and tired, carrying expensive equipment around me, just to take one picture of a random person I will probabily never meet again. But it was a great picture.
The same way it goes in computer science. I wasn't a great student, and only because of people that were doing their job out of passion I made it so far, so I will continue doing things my way.

I'll keep my articles shot and concise, because I always hated to read a lot just to get one idea. These articles will be sort of a user manual for whatever the experience I share was. It is called 'A Z6 Story' because the idea of finally implementing a blog came to the surface after starting to shoop with a Nikon Z6. When the last camera broke, it wasn't just a replacement, but a questions of wether I quit for a while or not.
